Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Entrainment and Task Success in Team Conversations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Teams, rather than individuals, are now the usual generators of scientific knowledge. How to optimize team interactions is a passionately pursued topic across several disciplines. This research hypothesizes that linguistic entrainment, or the convergence of linguistic properties of spoken conversation, may serve as a valid and relatively easy-to-collect measure that is predictive of team success. From the perspective of developing interventions for team innovation, organizations could unobtrusively measure team effectiveness using entrainment, and intervene with training to aid teams with low entrainment. Similar interventions would be useful for conversational agents that monitor and facilitate group interactions. The work could also support the development of browsers or data mining applications for corpora such as team meetings or classroom discussions.

To date, most studies of entrainment have focused on conversational dyads rather than the multi-party conversations typical of teams. The technical objective of this research is to develop, validate and evaluate new measures of linguistic entrainment tailored to multi-party conversations. In particular, the first research goal is to develop multi-party entrainment measures that are computable using language technologies, and that are both motivated and validated by the literature on teams. The second goal is to demonstrate the utility of these measures in being associated with team processes and predicting team success. The supporting activities include 1) collection of an experimentally-obtained corpus where teams collaborate on a task where they converse, and where a team process intervention manipulates likely entrainment, 2) development of a set of entrainment measures for multi-party dialogue, 3) use of standard psychological teamwork measures for convergent validity and random conversations for divergent validity, 4) exploration of how the team factors of gender composition and participation equality impact group entrainment, and 5) evaluation of the utility of measuring entrainment for predicting team and dialogue success.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Teams, rather than individuals, are now the usual generators of scientific knowledge. How to optimize team interactions is a passionately pursued topic across several disciplines. This research hypothesized that linguistic entrainment, or the convergence of linguistic properties of spoken conversation, may serve as a valid and relatively easy-to-collect measure that is predictive of team outcomes. However, most prior studies of entrainment  focused on conversational dyads rather than the multi-party conversations typical of teams. The technical objective of this research was to develop, validate and evaluate new measures of linguistic entrainment tailored to multi-party conversations. In particular, the first research goal was to develop multi-party entrainment measures that are computable using language technologies, and that are both motivated and validated by the literature on teams. The second goal was to demonstrate the utility of these measures in being associated with team processes and predicting team success. The supporting activities included 1) collection of an experimentally-obtained corpus where teams collaborated on a task where they conversed, and where a team process intervention manipulated likely entrainment, 2) development of a set of entrainment measures for multi-party dialogue, 3) use of standard psychological teamwork measures for convergent validity and random conversations for divergent validity, 4) exploration of how the team factors of gender composition and participation equality impact group entrainment, and 5) evaluation of the utility of measuring entrainment for predicting team outcomes.

The following were the major contributions from the perspective of intellectual merit. First, we explored the relation between entrainment on acoustic-prosodic and lexical features and showed that they correlated. In addition, we showed that a multi-modal model using entrainment features from both of these modalities outperformed uni-modal models at predicting team outcomes.  Second, we developed multi-party entrainment measures which utilized dynamics of entrainment in groups at both global and local settings. As for global entrainment, we created a weighted convergence measure based on group dynamics. As for local multi-party measures, we proposed several novel approaches to learn a vector embedding representation by encoding the structure of multi-party entrainment graphs. The positive results of both the global and local settings indicated the importance of incorporating entrainment dynamics in groups.  Finally, we proposed a novel approach to incorporate a team-level factor of gender-composition to enhance the multi-party entrainment measures. We also discovered relationships between entrainment and demographic and personality factors. While our work was focused on spoken dialogues, we believe that the methods we developed will  be useful for analyzing data from multi-party textual contexts such as twitter and discussion boards. 

From the broader impact perspective, we have created a corpus that has been made freely available to others for research purposes. This corpus will support recent efforts to increase scientific reproducibility. In addition, our corpus may facilitate new research in computational social science, as it can support data-driven investigation of other aspects of team dynamics and communication beyond entrainment. As for potential impacts on society, from the perspective of developing interventions for team innovation, organizations could unobtrusively measure team effectiveness using entrainment, and intervene with training to aid teams with low entrainment. Similar interventions would be useful for conversational agents that monitor and facilitate group interactions. The work could also support the development of browsers or data mining applications for corpora such as team meetings or classroom discussions.
